thread.section_title: Rick Gosselin Sports Columns - Sports News for Dallas, Texas
thread.title: Cowboys' survival guide with Brandon Weeden at QB
thread.title_full: Gosselin: Cowboys' survival guide with Brandon Weeden at QB | Dallas Morning News

author: Gosselin
title: Cowboys' survival guide with Brandon Weeden at QB
text:
The first half was a nightmare for Steve Beuerlein.
Filling in for an injured Troy Aikman in a 1991 game at Philadelphia, Beuerlein completed only two of 17 passes for 17 yards against the Eagles in the opening 30 minutes, and his Cowboys trailed 10-5. At halftime, Cowboys coach Jimmy Johnson pulled Beuerlein aside.
"You're playing great," Johnson said. "Listen, all we have to do is make a few plays in the second half and we're all set. You're protecting the ball, you're throwing it away, you're not giving them any short fields."
The Eagles had one of the great defenses of that era with Reggie White, Jerome Brown, Clyde Simmons, Seth Joyner, Eric Allen, Andre Waters and Wes Hopkins. But the offensive game plan was working out exactly as planned by Johnson: Offer the Eagles no gifts. Beuerlein threw a touchdown pass to Michael Irvin in the second half, and the Cowboys prevailed 25-13.
The Cowboys survived despite a 9-of-31 passing performance by Beuerlein for 145 yards. They survived because Beuerlein didn't turn the ball over. No interceptions, no fumbles and only one sack against a team that led the NFL in defense, sacks and takeaways that season.
And that's what any NFL team wants from its backup quarterback: mistake-free football. That's how you survive when your Pro Bowl starter can't go. And that's the challenge facing Brandon Weeden on Sunday as he embarks on what looms as an eight-week engagement filling in for Tony Romo.
The Cowboys were a 6-5 team in 1991 when Beuerlein stepped in for Aikman in the second half of a game against Washington. He threw a fourth-quarter TD pass that day in a 24-21 triumph over the Redskins -- the first of five consecutive victories engineered by Beuerlein to give Jerry Jones and Jimmy Johnson their first playoff berth on the road to a dynasty.
Beuerlein threw 111 consecutive passes without an interception covering his first four games filling in for Aikman. Mistake-free football allowed Beuerlein to survive in a role that produces far more failures than success stories.
Aikman was the first option for the Cowboys at quarterback. He's the guy the Cowboys wanted on the field. Beuerlein was the second option -- the quarterback the Cowboys didn't want on the field.
Since 2000, when NFL teams league-wide have been able to line up their first option at quarterback -- the Tom Bradys, Peyton Mannings and Ben Roethlisbergers -- they have won 52.5 percent of their games. But when teams have been forced to go to their second option -- the Bruce Gradkowskis, Mike Glennons and Jimmy Clausens -- they have managed to win only 44 percent of the time.
There have been some notable exceptions.
Brady went 11-3 in 2001 when he stepped in for an injured Drew Bledsoe, delivering the Patriots their first NFL championship that season. Roethlisberger went 13-0 as a rookie filling in for injured Tommy Maddox at Pittsburgh in 2004, quarterbacking the Steelers to the AFC title game.
But for every Brady and Roethlisberger, there are five Gradkowskis, Glennons, Clausens, Case Keenums and John Skeltons. There's a reason clubs are willing to award their first option at quarterback $100 million contracts -- but give their second option only a fraction of that in salary. You ask your first option to win games. You ask your second option not to lose them.
"The goal was to get out of that game without turning the ball over and, when we had a chance to make plays, we had to make them," recalled Beuerlein, who now works as an NFL analyst for CBS. "The quickest way out if you're a backup quarterback is to turn the ball over. They're not going to be overly patient if you can't protect the football."
Last season, only 16 teams kept their starting quarterback on the field for all 16 games. Those 16-game starters produced nine of the 12 playoff berths and won 58 percent of their games. The other 16 teams combined to win only 37.5 percent of the time they had their backup quarterbacks on the field, including a loss by Weeden in his lone start for the Cowboys.
Weeden threw twice as many interceptions (two) as touchdowns that day in a 28-17 home loss to the Cardinals. Since winning their last Super Bowl in the 1995 season, the Cowboys are 18-29 with backup quarterbacks on the field.
What the Cowboys need are more Beuerleins, more wins and fewer turnovers -- starting Sunday when Weeden hits the field to keep in an attempt to keep a playoff contender afloat against the Atlanta Falcons.
Listen to Rick Gosselin at 10:50 a.m. Tuesdays on Sportsradio 1310 AM/96.7 FM The Ticket with Norm Hitzges.
